instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hello. I got this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board in that was pretty badly liquid damaged. Most of the damage was around the backlight circuit and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>'s. The board was originally stuck on 5v and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was only 0.7v and 0.068 in diode mode. I removed <CAPACITOR>C6456</CAPACITOR> and the diode mode value on PPBUS went up to 0.410 and now I get 12.3v, but still 5v on amp meter. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> was 0v, so I replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and had to replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> also and that got me 20v back, but no amps. Now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> is 3.3v, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 0.9v, but seems to have the correct diode mode value of 0.398. I found small amount of corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>, so I replaced that chip and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> at the same time, but still have only 0.9v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Any idea what else could be causing this or what else to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can't expect <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, if is not enabled.
Check LDO voltages of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

Did you try DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have 0.9v on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> so it does seem to be enabled somehow. The 3V3 enable signal for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is just a test point that does not go to any other chip. <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is powered by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL>, which is also 0.9v because its comes from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. So I do not have any voltages that come from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> since it is not turning on. DFU also is not going to work if I am missing all voltages from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you found some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>, post the resistances between:
- pin 3 (high side MOSFET gate) of <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and pin 24 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>,
- pin 5 (low side MOSFET gate) of <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and pin 27 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>,
- any pin of L7690 inductor and pin 17 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>,
- any pin of L7690 inductor and pin 18 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.

Please also post the resistance to ground on pin 29 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> as it seems you have a non-working LDO5 output as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Don't be so sure; why didn't check before?
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> LDO block is powered from <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> (via <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>), which you've said is present.
T2 requires only AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages to go into DFU.
Also need SSD voltages, to complete DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I checked the resistances on <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and they all match vs a good board. I was not aware that the LDO block of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> was powered by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>. So based on the voltages below, it looks like <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is the issue?

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> - .924v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VINRTC_R</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.476v
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT_R</SIGNAL> - 1.814v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="tcampbell34, post: 82653, member: 7922"]
I checked the resistances on <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and they all match vs a good board.
[/QUOTE]
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 5371, member: 1"]
There are reasons for what we are asking you to do. There are constants. Throwing in other variables will lower the consistency of quality in the advice we offer (...) If you do not provide answers to all questions, we will let the thread die.
[/QUOTE]
You have been asked for more than just resistances on <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> low voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is powered up (from <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>), but fails to generate several LDO rails.
If none of them is shorted, or has low ohm resistance to ground, then change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
